      Collins, G. G.; Sandler, M.; Williams, E. D.; Youdim, M. B. Multiple Forms Of Human Brain Mitochondrial Monoamine Oxidase. Nature 1970, 225, 817– 820,  DOI: 10.1038/225817a0
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Multiple forms of human brain mitochondrial monoamine oxidase
      Collins, Godfrey G. S.; Sandler, Merton; Williams, Edward Dillwyn; Youdim, Moussa B. H.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1970), 225 (5235), 817-20CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
      The presence of at least 4 monoamine oxidase (I) isoenzymes was obsd. in human brain. Their sp. activities differed from one area to another. It was suggested that a simple regulatory mechanism existed by which an in traneuronal concn. of a particular amine was accompanied by the activation of a relatively specific isoenzyme of I.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE3cXht1yrurs%253D&md5=6d48451a49211b914136a880d842f64b
    8. 8
      Johnston, J. P. Some Observations Upon A New Inhibitor Of Monoamine Oxidase In Brain Tissue. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1968, 17, 1285– 1297,  DOI: 10.1016/0006-2952(68)90066-X
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Some observations on a new inhibitor of monoamine oxidase in brain tissue
      Johnston, J. P.
      Biochemical Pharmacology (1968), 17 (7), 1285-97CODEN: BCPCA6; ISSN:0006-2952.
      The inhibition of monoamine oxidase (MAO) in vitro and in vivo by N-methyl-N-propargyl-3-(2,4-dichlorophenoxy)propylamine-HCl (M&B 9302) is described. The kinetics of the MAO-M&B 9302 reaction show a unique abnormality as compared with known inhibitors. The plot of percent inhibition vs. concn. of M&B 9302 does not show a simple sigmoid curve, but reveals a pair of sigmoid curves joined by a horizontal section where the inhibition is invariant. The hypothesis that in the enzyme prepn., the MAO is a binary system of enzymes, each of which has a detectably different sensitivity to this particular inhibitor, is put forward and discussed. Evidence after dialysis supports this hypothesis.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF1cXktlCnsro%253D&md5=9987689810991f980e64f5b24665af02
    9. 9
      Knoll, J.; Magyar, K. Some Puzzling Pharmacological Effects Of Monoamine Oxidase Inhibitors. Adv. Biochem. Psychopharmacol. 1972, 5, 393– 408
      [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Puzzling pharmacological effects of monoamine oxidase [MAO] inhibitors
      Knoll, J.; Magyar, K.
      Advances in Biochemical Psychopharmacology (1972), 5 (), 393-408CODEN: ABPYBL; ISSN:0065-2229.
      A discussion and review with 17 refs. of some dissimilar effects various monoamine oxidase inhibitors may have on the metabolism of biogenic amines. Studies with the optical isomers of Deprenil [2079-54-1] indicate that multiple forms of the enzyme monoamine oxidase may exist.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE3sXhsA%253D%253D&md5=8a0fe1c36cedef71af1bde3b408913f9
    10. 10
      O’Carroll, A. M.; Fowler, C. J.; Phillips, J. P.; Tobbia, I.; Tipton, K. F. The Deamination Of Dopamine By Human Brain Monoamine Oxidase. Specificity For The Two Enzyme Forms In Seven Brain Regions. Naunyn-Schmiedeberg’s Arch. Pharmacol. 1983, 322, 198– 202,  DOI: 10.1007/BF00500765
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      The deamination of dopamine by human brain monoamine oxidase. Specificity for the two enzyme forms in seven brain regions
      O'Carroll, Anne Marie; Fowler, Christopher J.; Phillips, Jack P.; Tobbia, Iqdam; Tipton, Keith F.
      Naunyn-Schmiedeberg's Archives of Pharmacology (1983), 322 (3), 198-202CODEN: NSAPCC; ISSN:0028-1298.
      The deamination of dopamine (I) [51-61-6] was studied in 7 regions of human brain. Both A and B forms of monamine oxidase (MAO) [9001-66-5] were active towards I. The ratio of activities of MAO-A:MAO-B varied considerably from brain region to brain region, from about 1:1 for the cerebral and cerebellar cortex to about 1:2 for the pons and medulla oblongata. Enzyme titrn. studies and comparisons of the substrate specificities of MAO-A and MAO-B across the brain indicated that I was metabolized by the same MAO active centers as other monoamines. In the cerebral cortex, the Km values of MAO-A and -B towards I were 210 and 230 μM, resp., indicating that the relative contributions of these 2 forms towards the oxidn. of I will not be affected by changes in its concn.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL3sXitFSmtrk%253D&md5=ac03f33b62d3b917845cf5441904dac0
    11. 11
      Wouters, J. Structural Aspects Of Monoamine Oxidase And Its Reversible Inhibition. Curr Med. Chem. 1998, 5, 137– 162
      [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Structural aspects of monoamine oxidase and its reversible inhibition
      Wouters, Johan
      Current Medicinal Chemistry (1998), 5 (2), 137-162CODEN: CMCHE7; ISSN:0929-8673. (Bentham Science Publishers)
      A review with 152 refs. on the major structural aspects of MAO in relation to its primary sequence (site-directed mutagenesis, chimeric constructions) and secondary and three-dimensional structures. The consequences of the inhibition of monoamine oxidase are considered, mainly focusing on the new generations of reversible and selective MAO inhibitors (utilized as antidepressants antiparkinsonian agents). Recent efforts to design and develop these inhibitors are emphasized and discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXisVWmurw%253D&md5=02266afed9ece8986df53752e9aab5cd
    12. 12
      Carreiras, C.; Marco, J. L. Recent Approaches To Novel Anti-Alzheimer Therapy. Curr. Pharm. Des. 2004, 10, 3167– 3175,  DOI: 10.2174/1381612043383421
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Recent approaches to novel anti-Alzheimer therapy
      Carreiras, M. C.; Marco, J. L.
      Current Pharmaceutical Design (2004), 10 (25), 3167-3175CODEN: CPDEFP; ISSN:1381-6128. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
      A review. Insufficient cholinergic neurotransmission in AD is responsible for a progressive loss of cognition and motor capacities. The cholinergic hypothesis has provided the rationale for the current treatment approaches based on acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. However, recent data focus on the complex nature of AD and disclose the involvement of other neurotransmitters such as serotonin, noradrenalin, dopamine, histamine, excitatory amino acids, and neuropeptides, among others. Interestingly, recent research has revealed that in severe AD brains the levels of AChE are considerably reduced whereas BuChE activity increases, thus aggravating the toxicity of βA. In such instances, it is possible that BuChE may be a more suitable target than AChE. Oxidative stress has been implicated in CNS degenerative disorders such as AD and PD. Therefore, owing to their capacity to inhibit oxidative damage, MAOIs are potential candidates as anti-Alzheimer drugs. More recently, a novel drug - TV3326 - was designed, based upon 2 pharmacophores: the carbamate moiety from Rivastigmine, an AChE inhibitor; and the propargyl group from Rasagiline, a MAO inhibitor. This drug exhibits cholinesterase and selective brain MAO inhibitory activities, reduces apoptosis, and stimulates the processing of APPα, hence reducing the possibility of generation of the toxic βA. Thus, TV3326 may be expected to contribute pos. to the cognitive benefits of Alzheimer's patients. Anyhow, the development of drugs with several targets and diverse pharmacol. properties may conclusively demonstrate the most beneficial therapy.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXnslCktrY%253D&md5=a5c994c025780f2d02462eea9ad221e6
    13. 13
      Finberg, J. P. M. Update On The Pharmacology Of Selective Inhibitors Of Mao-A And Mao-B: Focus On Modulation Of Cns Monoamine Neurotransmitter Release. Pharmacol. Ther. 2014, 143, 133– 152,  DOI: 10.1016/j.pharmthera.2014.02.010
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13
      Update on the pharmacology of selective inhibitors of MAO-A and MAO-B: Focus on modulation of CNS monoamine neurotransmitter release
      Finberg, John P. M.
      Pharmacology & Therapeutics (2014), 143 (2), 133-152CODEN: PHTHDT; ISSN:0163-7258. (Elsevier)
      A review. Inhibitors of monoamine oxidase (MAO) were initially used in medicine following the discovery of their antidepressant action. Subsequently their ability to potentiate the effects of an indirectly-acting sympathomimetic amine such as tyramine was discovered, leading to their limitation in clin. use, except for cases of treatment-resistant depression. More recently, the understanding that: a) potentiation of indirectly-acting sympathomimetic amines is caused by inhibitors of MAO-A but not by inhibitors of MAO-B, and b) that reversible inhibitors of MAO-A cause minimal tyramine potentiation, has led to their re-introduction to clin. use for treatment of depression (reversible MAO-A inhibitors and new dose form MAO-B inhibitor) and treatment of Parkinson's disease (MAO-B inhibitors). The profound neuroprotective properties of propargyl-based inhibitors of MAO-B in preclin. expts. have drawn attention to the possibility of employing these drugs for their neuroprotective effect in neurodegenerative diseases, and have raised the question of the involvement of the MAO-mediated reaction as a source of reactive free radicals. Despite the long-standing history of MAO inhibitors in medicine, the way in which they affect neuronal release of monoamine neurotransmitters is still poorly understood. In recent years, the detailed chem. structure of MAO-B and MAO-A has become available, providing new possibilities for synthesis of mechanism-based inhibitors. This review describes the latest advances in understanding the way in which MAO inhibitors affect the release of the monoamine neurotransmitters dopamine, noradrenaline and serotonin (5-HT) in the CNS, with an accent on the importance of these effects for the clin. actions of the drugs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXkslGht7o%253D&md5=0f31959bad34842d4aaaba7b8162e5b8
    14. 14
      Yanez, M.; Padin, J. F.; Arranz-Tagarro, J. A.; Camina, M.; Laguna History And Therapeutic Use Of MAO-A Inhibitors: A Historical Perspective Of MAO-A Inhibitors As Antidepressant Drug. Curr. Med. Chem. 2012, 12, 2275– 2282,  DOI: 10.2174/156802612805220011
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      14
      History and therapeutic use of MAO-A inhibitors: a historical perspective of MAO-A inhibitors as antidepressant drug
      Yanez, Matilde; Padin, Juan Fernando; Arranz-Tagarro, Juan Alberto; Camina, Mercedes; Laguna, Reyes
      Current Topics in Medicinal Chemistry (Sharjah, United Arab Emirates) (2012), 12 (20), 2275-2282CODEN: CTMCCL; ISSN:1568-0266. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
      A review. Since the first generation of MAO inhibitors was developed, more than fifty years ago, this family of drugs has been ups and downs over the last decades. Actually, interest in MAO inhibitors is reviving and the emergence of new advances in the rational design of mols. and new techniques to predict the in vivo behavior has encouraged the research for new drugs with therapeutic potential in this area. The classic MAOIs have been widely used as antidepressants during the two decades after its introduction in clinic. Based on observations made on MAO inhibition by these drugs, it has been postulated hypothesis that have contributed to a better understanding of the mechanism and management of depressive disorders. However, exaggerated concerns about food and drug interactions relegated these drugs from the pharmaceutical landscape. The correct interpretation and the contextualization of side effects and the recent research findings, in which MAO selective inhibitors appear as promising agents in the treatment of emerging and high prevalence diseases, are placing these drugs again into the scientific and pharmacol. focus.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXlt1Gms78%253D&md5=d006b5b41bcc578adaaf401f5ce677ae

      Chimenti, F.; Maccioni, E.; Secci, D.; Bolasco, A.; Chimenti, P.; Granese, A.; Befani, O.; Turini, P.; Alcaro, S.; Ortuso, F.; Cirilli, R.; La Torre, F.; Cardia, M. C.; Distinto, S. Synthesis, Molecular Modeling Studies, And Selective Inhibitory Activity Against Monoamine Oxidase Of 1-Thiocarbamoyl-3,5-Diaryl-4,5-Dihydro-(1H)- Pyrazole Derivatives. J. Med.       15
      Synthesis, molecular modeling studies, and selective inhibitory activity against monoamine oxidase of 1-thiocarbamoyl-3,5-diaryl-4,5-dihydro-(1H)- pyrazole derivatives
      Chimenti, Franco; Maccioni, Elias; Secci, Daniela; Bolasco, Adriana; Chimenti, Paola; Granese, Arianna; Befani, Olivia; Turini, Paola; Alcaro, Stefano; Ortuso, Francesco; Cirilli, Roberto; La Torre, Francesco; Cardia, Maria C.; Distinto, Simona
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2005), 48 (23), 7113-7122CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A series of 1-thiocarbamoyl-3,5-diaryl-4,5-dihydro-(1H)-pyrazole derivs. I (R1 = 4-MeC6H4, 4-FC6H4, 2-thienyl; R2 = 4-ClC6H4, 4-Me6H4, 2-furanyl; R1 = R2 = 2-thienyl) have been synthesized and investigated for the ability to inhibit selectively the activity of the A and B isoforms of monoamine oxidase (MAO). All the synthesized compds. show high activity against both the MAO-A and the MAO-B isoforms with Ki values between 27 and 4 nM and between 50 and 1.5 nM, resp., except for a few derivs. whose inhibitory activity against MAO-B was in the micromolar range. Knowing that stereochem. may be an important modulator of biol. activity, we performed the semipreparative chromatog. enantiosepn. of the most potent, selective, and chiral compds. The sepd. enantiomers were then submitted to in vitro biol. evaluation. The selectivity of the (-)-(S)-I (R1 = 4-MeC6H4; R2 = 4-ClC6H4) enantiomer against MAO-B increases twice and a half, while the selectivity of the (-)-(S)-I (R1 = 4-FC6H4; R2 = 4-ClC6H4) enantiomer against MAO-A triples. Both the MAO-A and MAO-B isoforms resp. of the 1O5W and 1GOS models deposited in the Protein Data Bank were considered in the computational study. The docking study was carried out using several computational approaches with the aim of proposing possible binding modes of the MAO enantioselective compds.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhtFahs7vE&md5=6801dd2b87c1c60e9a50cd2947996dfd
    16. 16
      Manna, F.; Chimenti, F.; Bolasco, A.; Secci, D.; Bizzarri, B.; Befani, O.; Turini, P.; Mondovi, B.; Alcaro, S.; Tafi, A. Inhibition Of Amine Oxidases Activity By 1-Acetyl-3,5-Diphenyl-4,5-Dihydro-(1H)-Pyrazole Derivatives. Bioorg. Med. Chem. Lett. 2002, 12, 3629– 3633,  DOI: 10.1016/S0960-894X(02)00699-6

      16
      Inhibition of amine oxidases activity by 1-acetyl-3,5-diphenyl-4,5-dihydro-(1H)-pyrazole derivatives
      Manna, Fedele; Chimenti, Franco; Bolasco, Adriana; Secci, Daniela; Bizzarri, Bruna; Befani, Olivia; Turini, Paola; Mondovi, Bruno; Alcaro, Stefano; Tafi, Andrea
      Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2002), 12 (24), 3629-3633CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
      A novel series of 1-acetyl-3,5-diphenyl-4,5-dihydro-(1H)-pyrazole derivs. have been synthesized and investigated for the ability to inhibit selectively monoamine oxidases, swine kidney oxidase, and bovine serum amine oxidase. The newly synthesized compds. proved to be reversible and non-competitive inhibitors of all types of the assayed amine oxidases. Compds. inhibit monoamine oxidases potently, displaying low I50 values of particular interest. In particular 1-acetyl-3-(2,4-dihydroxyphenyl)-5-(3-methylphenyl)-4,5-dihydro-(1H)-pyrazole showed to be a potent monoamine oxidase inhibitor with a Ki of about 10-8 M. Further insights in the theor. evaluation of the possible interactions between the compds. and monoamine oxidase B have been developed through a computational approach.

    17. 17
      Secci, D.; Bolasco, A.; Chimenti, P.; Carradori, S. The State Of The Art Of Pyrazole Derivatives As Monoamine Oxidase Inhibitors And Antidepressant/Anticonvulsant Agents. Curr. Med. Chem. 2011, 18, 5114– 5144,  DOI: 10.2174/092986711797636090
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      17
      The state of the art of pyrazole derivatives as monoamine oxidase inhibitors and antidepressant/anticonvulsant agents
      Secci, D.; Bolasco, A.; Chimenti, P.; Carradori, S.
      Current Medicinal Chemistry (2011), 18 (33), 5114-5144CODEN: CMCHE7; ISSN:0929-8673. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
      A review. Monoamine oxidase plays a significant role in the control of intracellular concn. of monoaminergic neurotransmitters or neuromodulators and dietary amines. The rapid degrdn. of these mols. ensures the proper functioning of synaptic neurotransmission and is critically important for the regulation of emotional and other brain functions. The development of human MAO inhibitors led to important breakthroughs in the therapy of several neuropsychiatric disorders. Different families of heterocycles contg. 2 or 4 nitrogen atoms have been used as scaffolds for synthesizing selective monoamine oxidase inhibitors, but the early period of the MAO-inhibitors started with hydrazine derivs. Pyrazole, pyrazoline, and pyrazolidine derivs. can be considered as a cyclic hydrazine moiety. This scaffold also displayed promising antidepressant and anticonvulsant properties as demonstrated by different and established animal models. Diversely substituted pyrazoles, embedded with a variety of functional groups, are important biol. agents and a significant amt. of research activity has been directed towards this chem. class.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhs1ShtrzO&md5=cc2019fc83603bab23b443bd563f9c98
    18. 18
      Mathew, B.; Suresh, J.; Anbazhagan, S. Synthesis, Preclinical Evaluation And Antidepressant Activity Of 5-Substituted Phenyl-3-(Thiophen-2-Yl)-4, 5-Dihydro-1H-Pyrazole-1-Carbothioamides. EXCLI J. 2014, 13, 437– 445
      [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      18
      Synthesis, preclinical evaluation and antidepressant activity of 5-substituted phenyl-3-(thiophen-2-yl)-4, 5-dihydro-1H-pyrazole-1-carbothioamides
      Mathew Bijo; Suresh Jerad; Anbazhagan S
      EXCLI journal (2014), 13 (), 437-45 ISSN:1611-2156.
      A series of phenyl-3-(thiophen-2-yl)-4, 5-dihydro-1H-pyrazole-1-carbothioamides (TTa-TTg) were synthesized by the ring closure reaction of phenyl-1-(thiophen-2-yl) prop-2-en-1-ones with thiosemicarbazide in alcoholic basic medium. All the final derivatives were evaluated for their antidepressant and neurotoxicity screening. The structures of the compounds were characterized by IR, 1H NMR, 13C NMR, Mass and elemental analyses. Preclinical evaluation of the compounds were ascertained by in silico toxicity, blood-brain barrier and human oral absorption prediction. In this series, 5-(4-hydroxyphenyl)-3-(thiophen-2-yl)-4,5-dihydro-1H-pyrazole-1 carbothioamide (TTg) reduced immobility time 61.17 and 62.05 % in both force swimming and tail suspension test respectively at 10 mg/kg dose level when compared to the standard Imipramine without influencing the baseline locomotion. Moreover it was observed that the titled scaffold possessing electron withdrawing chlorine atom in the 4(th) position of aromatic ring of the scaffold also showed good the antidepressant activity. In conclusion, the behavioural investigation revealed that thiophene based pyrazolines having a carbothioamide tail unit in the N1 position may be therapeutically useful as potential antidepressant medications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC283ntFeqsQ%253D%253D&md5=484cf42aa579ba2f40eea552839b4bcd

      Synthesis and Selective Inhibitory Activity of 1-Acetyl-3,5-diphenyl-4,5-dihydro-(1H)-pyrazole Derivatives against Monoamine Oxidase
      Chimenti, Franco; Bolasco, Adriana; Manna, Fedele; Secci, Daniela; Chimenti, Paola; Befani, Olivia; Turini, Paola; Giovannini, Valentina; Mondovi, Bruno; Cirilli, Roberto; La Torre, Francesco
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2004), 47 (8), 2071-2074CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A novel series of 1-acetyl-3-(4-hydroxy- and 2,4-dihydroxyphenyl)-5-phenyl-4,5-dihydro-(1H)-pyrazole derivs. I [R = 4-OH, 2,4-(OH)2; R1 = 2-Cl, 3-Cl, 4-Cl, 3-Me, 4-Me, 2-OMe, 4-OMe, 2,4-(OMe)2] have been synthesized and investigated for the ability to selectively inhibit the activity of the A and B isoforms of monoamine oxidase (MAO). The new synthesized compds. I proved to be more reversible, potent, and selective inhibitors of MAO-A than of MAO-B. Knowing that stereochem. may be an important modulator of biol. activity, we performed the semi-preparative chromatog. enantiosepn. of the most potent, selective, and chiral compds., I [R = 4-OH; R1 = 2-OMe (II)] and I [R = 2,4-(OH)2; R1 = 2-OMe (III)]. The sepd. enantiomers were then submitted to in vitro biol. evaluation while increasing their inhibitory activity and A selectivity. The (-)-II enantiomer shows Ki(MAO-A) = 2 nM and SI = 165 000, (+)-II shows Ki(MAO-A) = 6 nM and SI = 166 666, (-)-III shows Ki(MAO-A) = 4 nM and SI = 80 000, and (+)-III shows Ki(MAO-A) = 7 nM and SI = 38 571.

      Synthesis, molecular modeling studies and selective inhibitory activity against MAO of N1-propanoyl-3,5-diphenyl-4,5-dihydro-(1H)-pyrazole derivatives
      Chimenti, Franco; Fioravanti, Rossella; Bolasco, Adriana; Manna, Fedele; Chimenti, Paola; Secci, Daniela; Rossi, Francesca; Turini, Paola; Ortuso, Francesco; Alcaro, Stefano; Cardia, Maria Cristina
      European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2008), 43 (10), 2262-2267CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
      A series of 1-propanoyl-3,5-diaryl-4,5-dihydro-1H-pyrazoles I (R1, R2 = Ph, 4-ClC6H4, 4-FC6H4, 4-MeC6H4, 4-MeOC6H4) was synthesized and assayed as inhibitors of MAO-A and MAO-B isoforms. I (R1 = Ph; R2 = 4-ClC6H4) to highlight the most relevant interactions in the mechanism of recognition within both the MAO-A and the MAO-B enzyme active sites.

      Synthesis and inhibitory activity against human monoamine oxidase of N1-thiocarbamoyl-3,5-di(hetero)aryl-4,5-dihydro-(1H)-pyrazole derivatives
      Chimenti, Franco; Carradori, Simone; Secci, Daniela; Bolasco, Adriana; Bizzarri, Bruna; Chimenti, Paola; Granese, Arianna; Yanez, Matilde; Orallo, Francisco
      European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2010), 45 (2), 800-804CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
      A series of N1-thiocarbamoyl-3,5-di(hetero)aryl-4,5-dihydro-(1H)-pyrazole derivs. has been synthesized and assayed for their ability to inhibit the activity of the A and B isoforms of human monoamine oxidase (hMAO). Some of these compds. were endowed with a selective inhibitory activity against hMAO-B in the micromolar range. The most active of the series is N1-thiocarbamoyl-3-(fur-2'-yl)-5-(4'-fluoro-phenyl)-4,5-dihydro-(1H)-pyrazole, with IC50 2.75 ± 0.81 μM value and selectivity ratio of 25, which is the best candidate for further investigations.

      3-(1H-Pyrrol-1-yl)-2-oxazolidinones as Reversible, Highly Potent, and Selective Inhibitors of Monoamine Oxidase Type A
      Mai, Antonello; Artico, Marino; Esposito, Monica; Sbardella, Gianluca; Massa, Silvio; Befani, Olivia; Turini, Paola; Giovannini, Valentina; Mondovi, Bruno
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2002), 45 (6), 1180-1183CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      3-(1H-Pyrrol-1-yl)-2-oxazolidinones (R)- and (S)-I [R = OH, OPMe, N3, NH2, NMe2] have been synthesized as pyrrole analogs of toloxatone (Humoryl), an antidepressant agent belonging to the 3-phenyl-2-oxazolidinone class, and their monoamine oxidase (MAO) type A and B inhibitory activities have been evaluated. The majority of I showed inhibitory activity against the A isoform of the enzyme higher than that exerted against the MAO-B, the sole exception being the (S)-I [R = NH2]. (R)-I [R = OMe], the most potent among test derivs., was 78-fold more potent than toloxatone.

      Close, W. J.; Tiffany, B. D.; Spielman, M. A. The Analgesic Activity of Some Benzoxazolone Derivatives. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1949, 71, 1265– 1268,  DOI: 10.1021/ja01172a036

      24
      The analgesic activity of some benzoxazolone derivatives
      Close, W. J.; Tiffany, Burris D.; Spielman, M. A.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1949), 71 (), 1265-8CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      3-Alkyl, 3-acyl, 3-dialkylaminoalkyl, and nuclear substituted derivs. (I) of 2(3H)-benzoxazolone (II) were synthesized; about 2/3 of them induced mild analgesia. Usually the I were prepd. by fusion of o-aminophenols (III), with improved yields of 76-90% by moderating the temp. and time. Most III, sensitive to air, were used as HCl salts. p-PrC6H4OH, 245 g. from PrC6H4OMe 289 g., 48% HBr 450, and HOAc 450 cc. refluxed 3 days, with dry HBr added the first 2 h., b0.75 79-80°. Modification of the method of Sandulesco and Girard (C.A. 25, 1228) gave a 300% increase in yield of p-HOC6H4COBu (IV): addn. of PhOH 72 g. in 144 cc. PhNO2 to 205 g. AlCl3 in 400 cc. PhNO2 at 10-12°, then dropwise addn. of 85 g. BuCOCl at 5-10°, addn. to ice and concd. HCl after 16 h., and NaOH extn. of the PhNO2 layer gave 87% IV, b0.7 150-60°. Clemmensen redn. of IV gave 85% p-AmC6H4OH, b1.4 103-7°. 4,2-Me(H2N)C6H3OH.HCl (90% from 4,2-Me(O2N)C6H3OH in abs. EtOH, Raney Ni, and 1000 lb. H at 75°, evapn. of the solvent, addn. of a slight excess of alc. HCl, and pptn. with Et2O), m. 222-4°. 4,2-Pr(O2N) C6H3OH [83% by a modification of the Baranger procedure (C.A. 26, 705)], b0.85 92-6°, nD25 1.5574; redn. with Raney Ni and H gave 98% 2-amino analog HCl salt, m. 245-52° (decompn.). Addn. of 65 g. p-AmC6H4OH in HOAc 65 to concd. HNO3 51 and HOAc 100 cc. during 2 h. at -5°, addn. to ice and 160 g. 10% NaOH, and C6H6 extn. gave 75% 4,2-Am(O2N) C6H3OH, b0.5 100-5°, nD25 1.5253; Raney Ni and H Substituents in I, Nuclear, Nitrogen, B.p., °C., mm., nD25, M.p., °C., Method, Yield, %, VII; None, H, , , , 139-40, A, 88, ..; None, Me, , , , 83-4, , , 1; None, Bu, 129-30, 1.3, 1.5316, , B, 62, 0; None, iso-Bu, , , , 63.5-5.0, B, 76, 0; None, Am, 140-2, 1.0, 1. 5268, , (b), 40, 0; None, iso-Am, 112-13, 0.4, 1.5248, 40-0.5, C, 90, 4 (a); None sec-Am, 132-4, 1.3, 1.5280, , B, 40, 3; None, Ac, , , , 92-4, , 66, 0; None, Allyl, 112-14, 0.5, 1.5536, , C, 66, 0; None, (c), , , , 171-3, C, 66, 3; 5-Me, H, , , , 128-9, A, 79, 0; 5-Me, Bu, 138-40, 1.2, 1.5300, , B, 67, 3; 5-Me, iso-Bu, , , , 61-2, B, 70, 1; 5-Me, Am, 136-8, 0.8, 1.5239, , B, 65, 2; 5-Me, iso-Am, 142-3, 1.3, 1.5230, , B, 65, 1; 5-Me, sec-Am, 130-3, 1.2, 1.5251, , B, 54, ..; 5-Pr, H, , , , 66.5-8, A, 79, 0; 5-Pr, Bu, 164-7, 1.0, 1.5196, , C, 95, 4 (a); 5-Pr, iso-Bu, 141-4, 1.2, 1.1597?, , B, 65, 3; 5-Pr, Am, 162-4, 1.4, 1.5157, , B, 66, 3; 5-Pr, iso-Am, 148-50, 0.8, 1.5167, , B, 66, 0; 5-Pr, sec-Am, 148-51, 1.1, 1.5197, , B, 38, 2; 5-Am, H, , , , 62-4, A, 90, ..; 5-Am, Me, , , , 55-6.5, (d), 96, ..; 5-Am, Pr, 167-70, 2.0, 1.5180, , C, 94, 0; 5-Am, iso-Bu, 146-8, 0.6, 1.5144, , C, 90, 2; 5-Am, Am, 178-80, 1.4, 1.5115, , C, 93, 0; 5,6-di-Me, H, , , , 177-8, (e), 68, 3; 5,6-di-Me, Et, , , , 86-7, (f), 73, 3; 5,6-di-Me, Bu, , , , 68-9, C, 80, 0; 5,6-di-Me, iso-Am, , , , 50-1, C, 86, 3; 5-MeO, H, , , , 170-2, A, 76, 3; 5-MeO, iso-Bu, , , , 57-8, C, 87, 3; 5-MeO, Am, 168-72, 1.4, 1.5299, , C, 92, 3; 5-MeO, Ac, , , , 102-3, (e), 95, 3; 6-Cl, H, , , , 194-5, (e), 81, 3; 6-Cl, Me, , , , 104-5, (d), 85, 0; 6-Cl, iso-Pr, , , , 91-2, C, 40, 2; 6-Cl, iso-Am, 157-63, 1.0, 1.5308, 46-7, C, 62, 4; (a) Tested on human volunteers with lower results; (b) prepd. with KOH in (CH2OH)2; (c) Et2NCH2CH2 HCl salt; two cryst. forms; lower-melting form, prisms from Me2CO-EtOH, m. 140-7° with resolidification to the higher-melting form; (d) prepd. with NaOMe and Me2SO4 in MeOH; (e) prepn. described in text; (f) prepd. with NaOMe and Et2SO4 in EtOH. gave 84% 4,2-Am(H2N)C6H3OH.HCl, m. 194° (from EtOH); free base m. 128° (from ligroin). 4,5,2-Me2(H2N)C6H2OH (V) (77% from NaHSO3 in basic soln. and 4,5,2-Me2(PhN2)C6H2OH) m. 171-5°. Addn. during 1.5 h. at -5 to 0° of 1 mol PhN2Cl to p-MeOC6H4OH 124, H2O 1200, and NaOH 120 g., and acidification gave 89% 4,2-MeO(PhN2)C6H3OH (VI), m. 72.5-3.5° (from EtOH). Addn. of NaHSO3 to VI 100, H2O 1000, and NaOH 100 g. on the steam bath until the color was gone, Et2O extn., neutralization of the aq. soln., and trituration of the dried ppt. with EtOH-HCl gave 85% 4,2-MeO(H2N)C6H3OH.HCl, crystd. from EtOH only with loss, m. 210-13° (decompn.) (pyrex tube evacuated to 0.5 mm.) (cf. m.p. of 171° of Roberts, et al., C.A. 29, 2934.7). Most I were prepd. by fusion with urea (Method A); thus 4,2-Pr(H2N)C6H3OH 470 and urea 300 g. heated in an oil bath at 180° 2 h., cooled, dil. acid added, then Et2O extn., gave 348 g. 5-Pr deriv. of II, b0.8 180-2°. Other I are given in the table. Dropwise addn. of 30 g. COCl2 in 400 cc. EtOAc to V 34.2 and anhyd. KOAc 59 g. in 600 cc. EtOAc, addn. of H2O and HCl, concn. of the EtOAc layer, soln. of the ppt. in boiling 10% NaOH, chilling, and acidifying the ppt. gave 68% 5,6-di-Me deriv. of II, m. 173-7°. Addn. of SO2Cl2 32 to HOAc 500 cc. and 50 g. II at 0°, letting stand 16 h. at room temp. and 1 h. on the steam bath, and addn. to cold H2O gave 81% 6-Cl deriv. of II, m. 189-94°. Cleavage of the ring with NaOH gave 5,2-Cl(H2N)C6H3OH, m. and mixed m.p. 152-4°. Method B for 3-substituted II: Addn. of 9.3 cc. iso-AmI to 0.2 g. 5-Pr deriv. of II in 60 cc. of 0.84 N KOH in Cellosolve, 6 h.' refluxing, concn. of the filtrate in vacuo, extn. from the H2O suspension with H2O, and washing with 5% NaOH gave 66% 3-isoamyl-5-Pr deriv. of II, b0.8 148-50°. Method C: 9.9 g. 5-MeO deriv. of II, then 9.6 cc. AmBr were added to 1.6 g. Na in 30 cc. Cellosolve (distd. over Na) in a N atm., refluxed 1 h., 0.69 g. Na in 10 cc. Cellosolve (prepd. under N) and 4.8 cc. AmBr added, and refluxed 1 h. more; addn. of HOAc, concn. in vacuo, treatment of the residue with Et2O and H2O, washing of the Et2O layer with 5% NaOH and HCl, and distn. gave 92% 3-amyl-5-methoxy deriv. of II, b1 166-74°. 3-Ac derivs. of I were prepd. (see table) by the following procedure: addn. of 5-MeO deriv. 9.9 of II to Na 1.6 g. in 50 cc. MeOH, concn., treatment of the dry residue with 25 cc. Ac2O 10 min., and addn. to H2O gave 95% 3-acetyl-5-methoxy deriv. of II, m. 100-3°. Analgesic activity in dogs was detd. by a modification of the method of Andrews and Workman (C.A. 35, 8102.3) with doses of 100-200 mg./kg., at which level toxic effects rarely appeared. The increase in pain threshold (VII in table) was: 0 = none; 1, doubtful; 2, < 10%; 3, 10-20%; 4, 20-30%. The best compds. had an activity comparable to that of aspirin, and were much weaker than Demerol.

      Milcent, R.; Akhnazarian, A.; Lensen, N. Synthesis of 1-(2-hydroxyphenyl)-2,4-Imidazolidinedione Derivatives Through Cyclic Transformations Of Ethyl 2-Oxo-3(2H)-Benzoxazoleacetate Derivatives. J. Heterocycl. Chem. 1996, 33, 1829– 1833,  DOI: 10.1002/jhet.5570330645
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      25
      Synthesis of 1-(2-hydroxyphenyl)-2,4-imidazolidinedione derivatives through cyclic transformations of ethyl 2-oxo-3(2H)-benzoxazoleacetate derivatives
      Milcent, Rene; Akhnazarian, Anna; Lensen, Nathalie
      Journal of Heterocyclic Chemistry (1996), 33 (6), 1829-1833CODEN: JHTCAD; ISSN:0022-152X. (HeteroCorporation)
      The Et 2-oxo-3(2H)-benzoxazoleacetate derivs. I (R1 = H, Cl, Me; R2 = H, Et) were prepd. By reaction with ammonia, primary amines or hydrazine, I were transformed into 1-(2-hydroxyphenyl)-2,4-imidazolidinedione derivs. (hydantoins) II (same R1, R2; R3 = Me, Et, NH2, etc.). Some of the new hydantoins II were treated with phosphorus oxychloride to give 2-oxoimidazo[2,1-b]benzoxazoles. Et 2-oxo-3(2H)-benzoxazolepropionate was prepd. by a Michael reaction of Et acrylate with a 2-benzoxazolone. Cyclic transformation were not obsd. with Et 2-oxo-3(2H)-benzoxazolepropionate in the presence of ammonia or alkylamine.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXotFCkug%253D%253D&md5=39e9bd723528db9fe9567c6074636abd
    26. 26
      Çakir, B.; Yildirim, E.; Ercanli, T.; Erol, K.; Sahin, M. F. Synthesis And Anticonvulsant Activity Of Some (2/4-Substituted)Benzaldehyde (2-Oxobenzothiazolin-3-Yl)Acetohydrazones. II Farmaco 1999, 54, 842– 845,  DOI: 10.1016/S0014-827X(99)00110-X
      [Crossref], [PubMed], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    27. 27
      Gökçe, M.; Geciken, A. E.; Yildirim, E.; Tosuni, A. U. Synthesis And Anticonvulsant Activity Of 5-Chloro-2(3H)-Benzoxazolinone-3-Acetyl-2-(O/P-Substituted Benzal) Hydrazone Derivatives. Arzneimittelforschung 2008, 58, 537– 542,  DOI: 10.1055/s-0031-1296554
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      27
      Synthesis and anticonvulsant activity of 5-chloro-2(3H)-benzoxazolinone-3-acetyl-2-(o/p-substituted benzal) hydrazone derivatives
      Gokce Mehtap; Geciken Ahmet Emin; Yildirim Engin; Tosuni Ali Ulvi
      Arzneimittel-Forschung (2008), 58 (11), 537-42 ISSN:0004-4172.
      It is well known that some hydrazone derivatives of both 2-oxobenzoxazoline and 2-oxobenzothiazoline exhibit potent anticonvulsant activity. In order to investigate the effects of structural modifications on the biological properties, 14 new hydrazones of 5-chloro-2(3H)-benzox-azolinone-3-acetyl hydrazide were synthesized. The chemical structures of the synthesized compounds were established by IR, 1H-NMR spectral analyses and elementary analyses. The anticonvulsant activities of the title compounds were tested by the penthylenetetrazole induced seizure test. 5-Chloro-2(3H)-benz-oxazolinone-3-acetyl-2-(o-methoxy-benzaldehyde)-hydrazone 4d, 5-chloro-2(3H)-benzoxazolinone-3-acetyl-2-(o-methybenzaldehyde)-hydrazone 4g, 5-chloro-2(3H)-benzoxazolinone-3-acetyl-2-(p-methylbenzaldehyde)-hydrazone 4h, 5-chloro-2(3H)-benzoxazolino-ne-3-acetyl-2-(p-nitrobenzaldehyde)-hydrazone 4m, and 5-chloro-2(3H)-benzox-azolinone-3-acetyl-2-(p-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde)-hydrazone 4n were found more active than phenytoin (CAS 57-41-0) in the tests.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD1M%252Fms1ejtQ%253D%253D&md5=943dad3712dc1f8c1e8cfdce80562baf
    28. 28
      Salgin-Gökşen, U.; Gokhan-Kelekci, N.; Goktas, O.; Koysal, Y.; Kilic, E.; Isik, S.; Aktay, G.; Ozalp, M. 1-Acylthiosemicarbazides, 1,2,4-triazole-5(4H)-thiones, 1,3,4-thiadiazoles and hydrazones containing 5-methyl-2-benzoxazolinones: Synthesis, Analgesic-Anti-Inflammatory And Antimicrobial Activities. Bioorg. Med. Chem. 2007, 15, 5738– 5751,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bmc.2007.06.006
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      28
      1-Acylthiosemicarbazides, 1,2,4-triazole-5(4H)-thiones, 1,3,4-thiadiazoles and hydrazones containing 5-methyl-2-benzoxazolinones: synthesis, analgesic-anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial activities
      Salgin-Goksen Umut; Gokhan-Kelekci Nesrin; Goktas Ozgur; Koysal Yavuz; Kilic Ekrem; Isik Samil; Aktay Goknur; Ozalp Meral
      Bioorganic & medicinal chemistry (2007), 15 (17), 5738-51 ISSN:0968-0896.
      Acetic acid hydrazide containing 5-methyl-2-benzoxazolinone (4) was synthesized by the condensation of 2-(5-methyl-2-benzoxazolinone-3-yl)acetate with hydrazine hydrate. Thiosemicarbazide derivatives (5a-5d) were afforded by the reaction of corresponding compound 4 with substituted isothiocyanates. The cyclization of compounds 5a-5d in the presence of triethylamine resulted in the formation of compounds 6a-6d containing 1,2,4-triazole ring. On the other hand, the treatment of compounds 5a-5d with orthophosphoric acid caused the conversion of side chain of compounds 5a-5d into 1,3,4-thiadiazole ring: thus, compounds 7a-7c were obtained. The treatment of compound 4 with aromatic aldehydes resulted in the formation of arylidene hydrazides as cis-trans conformers (8a-8e). The structures of the compounds were elucidated by spectral and elemental analysis. While most compounds were exhibiting high activity in the analgesic-anti-inflammatory field, most of them were found to be inactive against bacteria and fungi.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD2srgt1Glsw%253D%253D&md5=33ad7908138a83bb8e5f4a8629b5906a
    29. 29
      Davey, W.; Tivey, D. J. Chalcones and Related Compounds. 4. Addition of Hydrogen Cyanide to Chalcones. J. Chem. Soc. 1958, 1230– 1236,  DOI: 10.1039/jr9580001230
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29
      Chalcones and related compounds. IV. Addition of hydrogen cyanide to chalcones
      Davey, W.; Tivey, D. J.
      Journal of the Chemical Society (1958), (), 1230-6CODEN: JCSOA9; ISSN:0368-1769.
      cf. C.A. 51, 10450h. Optimum preparative conditions for RC6H4CH:CHCOC6H4R' (I) were established and new I were prepd. Procedures for the addn. of HCN to I and hydrolysis of the adducts were improved and new lactones, pyridazinones, and diols prepd. from these adducts. Comparative expts. showed that NaOH and NaOMe were generally more effective condensing agents than HCl, POCl3, or BF3 in the prepn. of 12 substituted I. Kohler and Chadwell's method (Org. Syntheses, Collective Vol. I, 78 (1941)) (method A) was modified in method B. Equimolar amts. of RC6H4CHO (II) and AcC6H4R' (III) mixed at 25° and if necessary made homogeneous with alc. at 30°, the mixt. made alk. to Brilliant Yellow with a 10% excess of 5N NaOH at 25-30° (external cooling), the mixt. kept homogeneous with addn. of alc. in 0.5-5.0 hrs., filtered, and washed with H2O, the filtrate dild. with H2O, and the product washed with H2O gave a product, crystd. once to give pure I. In method C, 1 mole II and 1 mole III in 200 ml. Ac2O were satd. with HCl below 30°, the mixt. kept 12 hrs. at room temp. and poured into ice and NH4OH, the oily product steam, distd., and the residue recrystd. Equimolar amts. of II and III liquefied by addn. of C6H6 were treated with a few drops of POCl3 at 30°, the mixt. kept at room temp. a few hrs., the product washed with 2N NH4OH and H2O, the C6H6 evapd. in vacuo, the residue steam-distd. and the product recrystd. (method D). In method E, 1 mole II was treated with 1 mole 48% BF3 in sufficient AcOH at 25° to dissolve II, the soln. treated slowly with 1 mole III at 25-30°, and the red mixt. kept 12 hrs. at room temp., treated with excess NaOAc soln., and steam-distd. to give a product requiring repeated recrystn. II (1 mole) in 200 ml. anhyd. MeOH added at 30° to 100 ml. MeOH contg 10 g. Na and the soln. treated with 1 mole III, the mixt. kept some hrs. at room temp. and filtered, the product washed, combined with the material recovered from the dild. filtrate, and recrystd. (method F). Results of comparative prepns. of I (R = R' = H) (Ia) were tabulated [method, % yield, reaction time in hrs., and m.p. (no. of recrystns.) given]: A, 89, 2, 52° (1); B, 76, 1, 55° (0); C, 50, 12, 53° (2); D, 48, 12, 52° (2); E, 53, 6, 52° (2); F, 71, 4, 52° (1). Similar results with substituted I were summarized [R, R', % yield (m.p.) for methods B, C, D, E, and F given]: p-MeO, H, 76 (75°), 50(72°), 47(73°), 52(70°), 61(72°); p-MeO, p-MeO, 81(100°), 66(99°), 50(100°), 62(97°), 75(98°); p-MeO, p-Me, 55(91°), -, -, 70(124°), -, -, 77(126°); p-Me, H, 42(94°), 30(95.5°), 20(96°), -, 45(95°); p-HO, H, 37(180°), 11(182°), 20(179°), 25(179°), 31(182°); H, p-MeO, 81(106°), 55(105°), 45(104°), -, 77(108°); P-O2N, H, 60(162°), 80(162°), 42(162°), 35(162°), 57(162°); H, m-O2N, 75(130°), 25(131°), 10(130°), -, tar; H, p-Me, 35(75°), 42(75°), 22(72°), 23(72°), -. HCN was added to la and I (R = p-MeO, R' = H) by the method of Allan and Kimball (Org. Syntheses, Coll. Vol. II, 498), but the method failed with I (R = H, R' = p-MeO) (Ib), I (R = R' = p-MeO) (Ic), and I (R = H, R' = p-HO). The method of Kohler and Leers (C.A. 28, 30646) gave a low yield of HCN adduct with Ib but failed with Ic. Ia (41.6 g.) in 700 ml. alc. stirred with cooling with slow addn. of 50 ml. 7N H2SO4, the mixt. heated to 50°, treated slowly with 50 g. KCN in 80 ml. H2O and the mixt. refluxed 5 min., dild. with 200 ml. H2O, kept 12 hrs. at 20°, and filtered, the solid product extd. 3 times with 100 ml. boiling alc., the ext. evapd., and the residue crystd. (alc.) gave 35 g. PhCH(CN)CH2Bz, m. 126°. Similarly high yields of adducts, RCH(CN)CH2COC6H4R' (IV) were obtained by the use of 1 mole H2SO4 and 2 moles KCN (R, R', m.p., and % yield given): Ph, p-MeO, 65°, 86; p-MeOC6H4, p-MeO, 113-14°, 66; p-HOC6H4, H, 173°, 68; 2,4-(MeO)2C6H3, p-MeOC6H4, 125-6°, 83; 3,4-(MeO)2C6H3, p-MeO, 105°, 79. Acid hydrolysis of IV was difficult, and the resultant acids, RCH(CO2H)CH2COR' (V), tended to sep. as oils. Conversion of IV into the Me esters, RCH(CO2Me)CH2COR' (VI) by boiling with HCl in MeOH and hydrolysis of VI with dil. NaOH gave good yields of V. IV (R = R' = H) (23.5 g.) in 200 ml. MeOH satd. with dry HCl at 25° and refluxed 1.5 hrs., 100 ml. MeOH distd., the concentrate dild. with 200 ml. H2O, the mixt. kept overnight at room temp. and filtered gave 24 g. VI (R = R' = Ph) (VIa), m. 103°. Similarly were prepd. the esters VI [R, R', m.p. (solvent) and % yield given]: Ph, p-MeOC6H4 (VIb), 96° (MeOH), 91; p-MeOC6H4, p-MeOC6H4 (VIc), 96-7° (MeOH), 85; p-HOC6H4, Ph (VId), 143-4° (MeOH), 83; 2,4-(MeO)2C6H3, p-MeOC6H4, 128-9° (EtOH), 83; 3,4-(MeO)2C6H3, p-MeOC6H4, 74-5° (MeOH), 73. VIa (26.8 g.) refluxed 2 hrs. in 100 ml. alc. with 100 ml. 2N NaOH, the soln. treated with 120 ml. 2N HCl, and the mixt. kept overnight at room temp. and filtered gave 23 g. V (R = R' = Ph) (Vc), m. 152° (alc.). Similarly were obtained the acids V [R, R', m.p. (solvent) and % yield given]: Ph, p-MeOC6H4 (Vb), 139-40° (alc.), 93; p-MeOC6H4, p-MeOC6H4 (Vc), 163-4° (alc.), 91; p-HOC6H4, Ph (Vd), 143-4° (MeOH), 83; 2,4-(MeO)2C6H3, p-MeOC6H4, 127-8° (alc.), 80; 3,4-(MeO)2C6H3, p-MeOC6H4, 179-80° (alc.), 80. Va (12.7 g.) refluxed 3 hrs. in 25 ml. Ac2O and the mixt. poured into cold H2O, kept 1 hr., and filtered, the ppt. (10 g.) taken up in 50 ml. boiling alc., and the cooled soln. filtered gave 2.6 g. material, recrystd. (alc.) to give 1.7 g. high melting unsatd. 4-hydroxy-2,4-diphenyl-2-butenoic lactone (VII), O.CO.CR:CH.CHR' (R = R' = Ph) (VIIa), m. 283-5°. The filtrate dild. with 15 ml. H2O and the 6.1 g. dried product, m. 91°, recrystd. (alc.) yielded 3.7 g. low melting isomeric lactone (VIII), O.CO.CHR.CH:CR' (R = R' = Ph) (VIIIa), m. 107-8°. Similarly, from Vb, Vc, and Vd were prepd. the corresponding pairs of isomeric lactones (reflux time in hrs., lactones, and m.p. given): 2, VIIb, 250-60° (decompn.), VIIIb, 92; 1.5, VIIc, 255-60° (decompn.), VIIIc, 106-7°; 1, VIId, 282-4° (decompn.), VIIId, 131-2. Va (5 g.) heated 2 hrs. at 165° and the cooled melt taken up in 30 ml. boiling alc., the filtered soln. cooled and filtered gave 0.2 g. VIIa. Concn. of the filtrate gave 3.7 g. VIIIa. Similarly, small amts. of VIIa were obtained by heating Va with alc. or AcOH. Rast mol. wt. detns. and repeated analyses confirmed the monomeric nature of the extremely insol. VII, and slightly favorable evidence was given by the infrared spectral bands of VIIc and VIIIc, ν 1763 and 1750 cm.-1, resp. (in nujol). VIIIa (2 g.) hydrogenated in 25 ml. alc. with 0.5 g. 10% Pd-C, the filtered soln. dild. with H2O, extd. 3 times with 20 ml. 2N Na2CO3, the ext. washed twice with 20 ml. Et2O, the aq. soln. acidified with HCl, the oily product extd. twice with 20 ml. Et2O, the ext. evapd. in vacuo, and the residue crystd. (petr. ether) gave 1.5 g. PhCH2CH2CHPhCO2H, m. 73-4°. VIa (5 g.) in 50 ml. alc. added slowly with stirring to 2 g. KBH4 in 100 ml. 19:1 alc.-H2O, the mixt. kept 5 hrs. at room temp. evapd. to 30 ml. and acidified with HCl, the viscous green sirupy extd. with C6H6, and the solidified product recrystd. (alc.) gave 3.5 g. satd. lactone (IX), O.CO.CHR.CH2.CHR' (R = R' = Ph) (IXa), m. 102° (alc.), also obtained by hydrogenation of 4 g. VIa in 50 ml. alc. with 1 g. Raney Ni and crystn. (pert. ether) of the product. Similarly with Pd-C were obtained 62% IX (R = Ph, R' = p-MeOC6H4), m. 77° (alc.), and 90% IX (R = R' = p-MeOC6H4), m. 136-7°(alc.). VIa (5 g.) extd. from a Soxhlet app. thimble into 150 ml. Et2O contg. 1.5 g. LiAlH4, the mixt. refluxed 2 hrs., treated with EtOAc and 100 ml. 2N H2SO4, the Et2O layer washed with H2O, the soln. dried, evapd., and the sirupy residue kept 7 days at 0° under petr. ether gave 3 g. HOCH2CHRCH2CHR'OH (X) (R = R' = Ph), m. 92°. Similarly were prepd. 33% X (R = Ph, R' = p-MeOC6H4), m. 48-50°; 81% X (R = R' = p-MeOC6H4), m. 80-90°; and gummy X (R = p-HOC6H4, R = Ph). VIa (20 g.) and 6.6 g. PhNHNH2 in 170 ml. AcOH heated 15 min. on a steam bath, the cooled soln. dild. with 100 ml. H2O, filtered, and the cryst. residue recrystd. (alc.) yielded 75% RCH.CO.NPh.N:CR'.CH2 (XI) (R = R' = Ph), m. 121-3°. By the same method, or with V in the place of VI, were prepd. 85% XI (R = Ph, R' = p-MeOC6H4), m. 94-5°, and 56% XI (R = R' = p-MeOC6H4), m. 123°, ν 1696, 1601, 1514, 1490 cm.-1, confirming the assigned pyridazine structure.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaG1cXmsFyhsQ%253D%253D&md5=ba4153fda21a436dfe582b2b6d4b8157

      Goksen, U. S.; Sarigul, S.; Bultinck, P.; Herrebout, W.; Dogan, I.; Yelekci, K.; Ucar, G.; Gokhan Kelekci, N. Absolute Configuration And Biological Profile Of Pyrazoline Enantiomers As MAO Inhibitory Activity. Chirality 2019, 31, 21– 33,  DOI: 10.1002/chir.23027
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      30
      Absolute configuration and biological profile of pyrazoline enantiomers as MAO inhibitory activity
      Goksen, Umut Salgin; Sarigul, Sevgi; Bultinck, Patrick; Herrebout, Wouter; Dogan, Ilknur; Yelekci, Kemal; Ucar, Gulberk; Gokhan Kelekci, Nesrin
      Chirality (2019), 31 (1), 21-33CODEN: CHRLEP; ISSN:0899-0042. (Wiley-Liss, Inc.)
      A new racemic pyrazoline deriv. was synthesized and resolved to its enantiomers using analytic and semipreparative high-pressure liq. chromatog. The abs. configuration of both fractions was established using vibrational CD. The in vitro monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitory profiles were evaluated for the racemate and both enantiomers sep. for the two isoforms of the enzyme. The racemic compd. and both enantiomers were found to inhibit hMAO-A selectively and competitively. In particular, the R enantiomer was detected as an exceptionally potent and a selective MAO-A inhibitor (Ki = 0.85 x 10-3 ± 0.05 x 10-3 μM and SI: 2.35 x 10-5), whereas S was detd. as poorer compd. than R in terms of Ki and SI (0.184 ± 0.007 and 0.001). The selectivity of the enantiomers was explained by mol. modeling docking studies based on the PDB enzymic models of MAO isoforms.

      admetSAR 2.0: web-service for prediction and optimization of chemical ADMET properties
      Yang, Hongbin; Lou, Chaofeng; Sun, Lixia; Li, Jie; Cai, Yingchun; Wang, Zhuang; Li, Weihua; Liu, Guixia; Tang, Yun
      Bioinformatics (2019), 35 (6), 1067-1069CODEN: BOINFP; ISSN:1367-4811. (Oxford University Press)
      AdmetSAR was developed as a comprehensive source and free tool for the prediction of chem. ADMET properties. Since its first release in 2012 contg. 27 predictive models, admetSAR has been widely used in chem. and pharmaceutical fields. This update, admetSAR 2.0, focuses on extension and optimization of existing models with significant quantity and quality improvement on training data. Now 47 models are available for either drug discovery or environmental risk assessment. In addn., we added a new module named ADMETopt for lead optimization based on predicted ADMET properties.

      Lipinski, C. A. Lead- And Drug-Like Compounds: The Rule-Of-Five Revolution. Drug Discovery Today: Technol. 2004, 1, 337– 341,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ddtec.2004.11.007
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      32
      Lead- and drug-like compounds: the rule-of-five revolution
      Lipinski, Christopher A.
      Drug Discovery Today: Technologies (2004), 1 (4), 337-341CODEN: DDTTB5; ISSN:1740-6749. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Citations in CAS SciFinder to the rule-of-five (RO5) publication will exceed 1000 by year-end 2004. Trends in the RO5 literature explosion that can be discerned are the further definitions of drug-like. This topic is explored in terms of drug-like physicochem. features, drug-like structural features, a comparison of drug-like and non-drug-like in drug discovery and a discussion of how drug-like features relate to clin. success. Physicochem. features of CNS drugs and features related to CNS blood-brain transporter affinity are briefly reviewed. Recent literature on features of non-oral drugs is reviewed and how features of lead-like compds. differ from those of drug-like compds. is discussed. Most recently, partly driven by NIH roadmap initiatives, considerations have arisen as to what tool-like means in the search for chem. tools to probe biol. space. All these topics frame the scope of this short review/perspective.

      34
      Synthesis, crystal structures and DFT studies of 1-[2-(5-methyl-2-benzoxazolinone-3-yl)acetyl]-3-phenyl-5-(3,4-dimethoxyphenyl)-4,5-dihydro-1H-pyrazole and 1-[2-(5-chloro-2-benzoxazolinone-3-yl)acetyl]-3-phenyl-5-(4-methoxyphenyl)-4,5-dihydro-1H-pyrazole
      Sahin, Zarife Sibel; Salgin-Goeksen, Umut; Goekhan-Kelekci, Nesrin; Isik, Samil
      Journal of Molecular Structure (2011), 1006 (1-3), 147-158CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The title compds., 1-[2-(5-methyl-2-benzoxazolinone-3-yl)acetyl]-3-phenyl-5-(3,4-dimethoxyphenyl)-4,5-dihydro-1H-pyrazole (5a) and 1-[2-(5-chloro-2-benzoxazolinone-3-yl)acetyl]-3-phenyl-5-(4-methoxyphenyl)-4,5-dihydro-1H-pyrazole (5b), were synthesized. The crystal and mol. structures of 5a and 5b have been detd. by elemental analyses, IR, 1H NMR, ESI-MS and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Mol. geometries of 5a and 5b in the ground state have been calcd. using the d. functional method (DFT) with B3LYP/6-31G(d,p) basis set and compared with the exptl. data. In addn., the mol. electrostatic potential maps and frontier MOs of 5a and 5b were performed.

      Synthesis, crystal structures and theoretical calculations of new 1-[2-(5-chloro-2-benzoxazolinone-3-yl)acetyl]-3,5-diphenyl-4,5-dihydro-(1H)-pyrazoles
      Goksen, Umut Salgin; Alpaslan, Yelda Bingol; Kelekci, Nesrin Gokhan; Isik, Samil; Ekizoglu, Melike
      Journal of Molecular Structure (2013), 1039 (), 71-83CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
      1-[2-(5-Chloro-2-benzoxazolinone-3-yl)acetyl]-3,5-diphenyl-4,5-dihydro-(1H)-pyrazoles I (R1 = R2 = R4 = H, R3 = OMe; R1 = R4 = H, R2 = R3 = OMe; R1 = Me, R2 = H, R3 = R4 = OMe) were synthesized. The crystal and mol. structures of the compds. I were detd. by elemental analyses, IR, 1H NMR, ESI-MS and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. DFT method with 6-31G(d,p) basis set was used to calc. the optimized geometrical parameters, vibrational frequencies and chem. shift values. The calcd. vibrational frequencies and chem. shift values were compared with exptl. IR and 1H NMR values. The results represented that there was a good agreement between exptl. and calcd. values of the compds. I. In addn., DFT calcns. of the compds., mol. electrostatic potentials (MEPs) and frontier MOs were performed at B3LYP/6-31G(d,p) level of theory. Furthermore, compds. were tested against three Gram-pos. bacteria: Staphylococcus aureus ATCC 29213 (American Type Culture Collection), methicillin resistant S. aureus (MRSA) ATCC 43300 and Enterococcus faecalis ATCC 29212; two Gram neg. bacteria: Escherichia coli ATCC 25922 and Pseudomonas aeruginosa ATCC 27853; and three fungi: Candida albicans ATCC 90028, Candida krusei ATCC 6258 and Candida parapsilosis ATCC 90018. In general, all of the compds. were found to be slightly active against tested microorganisms.

      Carpenter, T. S.; Kirshner, D. A.; Lau, E. Y.; Wong, S. E.; Nilmeier, J. P.; Lightstone, F. C. A Method to Predict Blood-Brain Barrier Permeability of Drug-Like Compounds Using Molecular Dynamics Simulations. Biophys. J. 2014, 107, 630– 641,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bpj.2014.06.024
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      36
      A Method to Predict Blood-Brain Barrier Permeability of Drug-Like Compounds Using Molecular Dynamics Simulations
      Carpenter, Timothy S.; Kirshner, Daniel A.; Lau, Edmond Y.; Wong, Sergio E.; Nilmeier, Jerome P.; Lightstone, Felice C.
      Biophysical Journal (2014), 107 (3), 630-641CODEN: BIOJAU; ISSN:0006-3495. (Cell Press)
      The blood-brain barrier (BBB) is formed by specialized tight junctions between endothelial cells that line brain capillaries to create a highly selective barrier between the brain and the rest of the body. A major problem to overcome in drug design is the ability of the compd. in question to cross the BBB. Neuroactive drugs are required to cross the BBB to function. Conversely, drugs that target other parts of the body ideally should not cross the BBB to avoid possible psychotropic side effects. Thus, the task of predicting the BBB permeability of new compds. is of great importance. Two gold-std. exptl. measures of BBB permeability are logBB (the concn. of drug in the brain divided by concn. in the blood) and logPS (permeability surface-area product). Both methods are time-consuming and expensive, and although logPS is considered the more informative measure, it is lower throughput and more resource intensive. With continual increases in computer power and improvements in mol. simulations, in silico methods may provide viable alternatives. Computational predictions of these two parameters for a sample of 12 small mol. compds. were performed. The potential of mean force for each compd. through a 1,2-dioleoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphocholine bilayer is detd. by mol. dynamics simulations. This system setup is often used as a simple BBB mimetic. Addnl., one-dimensional position-dependent diffusion coeffs. are calcd. from the mol. dynamics trajectories. The diffusion coeff. is combined with the free energy landscape to calc. the effective permeability (Peff) for each sample compd. The relative values of these permeabilities are compared to exptl. detd. logBB and logPS values. Our computational predictions correlate remarkably well with both logBB (R2 = 0.94) and logPS (R2 = 0.90). Thus, we have demonstrated that this approach may have the potential to provide reliable, quant. predictive BBB permeability, using a relatively quick, inexpensive method.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXht12msrrF&md5=70da942a59a290e480a88f2a1f4afb53

      Di, L.; Kerns, E. H.; Fan, K.; McConnell, O. J.; Carter, G. T. High Throughput Artificial Membrane Permeability Assay For Blood-Brain Barrier. Eur J. Med. Chem. 2003, 38, 223– 232,  DOI: 10.1016/S0223-5234(03)00012-6
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      37
      High throughput artificial membrane permeability assay for blood-brain barrier
      Di, Li; Kerns, Edward H.; Fan, Kristi; McConnell, Oliver J.; Carter, Guy T.
      European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2003), 38 (3), 223-232CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Editions Scientifiques et Medicales Elsevier)
      The recent advances in high throughput screening for biol. activities and combinatorial chem. have greatly expanded the no. of drug candidates. Rapid screening for BBB penetration potential early in drug discovery programs provides important information for compd. selection and guidance of synthesis for desirable CNS properties. In this paper, we discuss a modification of the parallel artificial membrane permeation assay (PAMPA) for the prediction of blood-brain barrier penetration (PAMPA-BBB). The assay was developed with 30 structurally diverse com. drugs and validated with 14 Wyeth Research compds. The PAMPA-BBB assay has the advantages of: predicting passive blood-brain barrier penetration with high success, high throughput, low cost, and reproducibility.

      38
      Is the forced swimming test a suitable model for revealing antidepressant activity?
      Borsini F; Meli A
      Psychopharmacology (1988), 94 (2), 147-60 ISSN:0033-3158.
      The forced swimming test is reviewed. This test appears to be suitable for detecting antidepressant activity in rats but not in mice. Difference in experimental procedure may account for the different sensitivity to drugs of the two animal species.

      Vaidya, A.; Pradhan, A.; Joshi, S. K.; Gopalakrishnan, S.; Dudani, I. Acquaintance With The Actuality: Community Diagnosis Programme Of Kathmandu Medical College At Gundu Village, Bhaktapur, Nepal. Kathmandu Univ. Med. J. 2008, 6, 128– 134
      [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      39
      Acquaintance with the actuality: community diagnosis programme of Kathmandu Medical College at Gundu village, Bhaktapur, Nepal
      Vaidya A; Pradhan A; Joshi S K; Gopalakrishnan S; Dudani I
      Kathmandu University medical journal (KUMJ) (2008), 6 (1), 128-34 ISSN:.
      INTRODUCTION: In Nepal, various field programs such as community diagnosis programmes (CDP) have been initiated to make the education of doctors, nurses and dentists more community oriented and relevant and suited to the health care scenario. Community diagnosis refers to the identification and quantification of the health problems in a community and identification of their correlates for the purpose of defining those individuals or groups at risk or those in need of health care. The article presents the main activities of community diagnosis as a core component of community-based education for the medical students at Kathmandu Medical College, Kathmandu, Nepal. METHODOLOGY: A 4 weeks' Community Diagnosis Programme was conducted by MBBS II students (9th Batch) of the Kathmandu Medical College under the supervision of the Department of Community Medicine in November 2006 in the rural community of Gundu VDC (village development committee). The tools used included pre-tested questionnaires, weighing machines, measuring tapes, stethoscopes and sphygmomanometers. After the data collection and compilation, the students presented their findings in oral presentations, accompanied by a written report, including essential recommendations for improving the health status of these communities. RESULTS: The students benefited from the necessary process of integrating clinical skills and a public health approach, so as to enhance their epidemiological thinking and be of greater use to the communities where they will practice. The community also benefited by achievement of behavioral changes leading to healthier lifestyles and increased awareness of health-related matters and their role in quality of life. CONCLUSIONS: CDP is a way to practically demonstrate that the link between a medical college and society is possible. That is, a medical college can serve the community and thus society, with specific activities to improve health and the skills of students who will serve as future health professionals.

      Petit-Demouliere, B.; Chenu, F.; Bourin, M. Forced Swimming Test In Mice: A Review Of Antidepressant Activity. Psychopharmacology 2005, 177, 245– 255,  DOI: 10.1007/s00213-004-2048-7
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      41
      Forced swimming test in mice: a review of antidepressant activity
      Petit-Demouliere, Benoit; Chenu, Franck; Bourin, Michel
      Psychopharmacology (Berlin, Germany) (2005), 177 (3), 245-255CODEN: PSCHDL; ISSN:0033-3158. (Springer GmbH)
      A review. Rationale: Among all animal models, the forced swimming test (FST) remains one of the most used tools for screening antidepressants. Objective: This paper reviews some of the main aspects of the FST in mice. Most of the sensitivity and variability factors that were assessed on the FST are summarized. Mechanisms: We have summarized data found in the literature of antidepressant effects on the FST in mice. From this data set, we have extrapolated information on baseline levels of strain, and sensitivity against antidepressants. Results: We have shown that many parameters have to be considered in this test to gain good reliability. Moreover, there was a fundamental inter-strain difference of response in the FST. Conclusions: The FST is a good screening tool with good reliability and predictive validity. Strain is one of the most important parameters to consider. Swiss and NMRI mice can be used to discriminate the mechanisms of action of drugs. CD-1 seems to be the most useful strain for screening purposes, but this needs to be confirmed with some spontaneous locomotor activity studies.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXhtVyltLrE&md5=d072eba578f8564ea4c6d15fb790d1a5

      Yan, H. C.; Cao, X.; Das, M.; Zhu, X. H.; Gao, T. M. Behavioral Animal Models Of Depression. Neurosci Bull 2010, 26, 327– 337,  DOI: 10.1007/s12264-010-0323-7
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      42
      Behavioral animal models of depression
      Yan Hua-Cheng; Cao Xiong; Das Manas; Zhu Xin-Hong; Gao Tian-Ming
      Neuroscience bulletin (2010), 26 (4), 327-37 ISSN:.
      Depression is a chronic, recurring and potentially life-threatening illness that affects up to 20% of the population across the world. Despite its prevalence and considerable impact on human, little is known about its pathogenesis. One of the major reasons is the restricted availability of validated animal models due to the absence of consensus on the pathology and etiology of depression. Besides, some core symptoms such as depressed mood, feeling of worthlessness, and recurring thoughts of death or suicide, are impossible to be modeled on laboratory animals. Currently, the criteria for identifying animal models of depression rely on either of the 2 principles: actions of known antidepressants and responses to stress. This review mainly focuses on the most widely used animal models of depression, including learned helplessness, chronic mild stress, and social defeat paradigms. Also, the behavioral tests for screening antidepressants, such as forced swimming test and tail suspension test, are also discussed. The advantages and major drawbacks of each model are evaluated. In prospective, new techniques that will be beneficial for developing novel animal models or detecting depression are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3cnpsVKltw%253D%253D&md5=17d9e33165a04a820c029c29c4d8b5c8

      [Crossref], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.

      Xu, Y.; Li, S.; Chen, R.; Li, G.; Barish, P. A.; You, W.; Chen, L.; Lin, M.; Ku, B.; Pan, J.; Ogle, W. O. Antidepressant-Like Effect Of Low Molecular Proanthocyanidin In Mice: Involvement Of Monoaminergic System. Pharmacol., Biochem. Behav. 2010, 94, 447– 453,  DOI: 10.1016/j.pbb.2009.10.007
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      44
      Antidepressant-like effect of low molecular proanthocyanidin in mice: Involvement of monoaminergic system
      Xu, Ying; Li, Shan; Chen, Ruijie; Li, Gaowen; Barish, Philip A.; You, Wenting; Chen, Ling; Lin, Mengmeng; Ku, Baoshan; Pan, Jianchun; Ogle, William O.
      Pharmacology, Biochemistry and Behavior (2010), 94 (3), 447-453CODEN: PBBHAU; ISSN:0091-3057. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Proanthocyanidin is a phenolic product present in plants which has antioxidant, antinociceptive and neuroprotective properties, without inducing significant toxicol. effects. The present study tested the hypothesis that low mol. proanthocyanidin from grapes that has optimized bioavailability, would exert antidepressant-like activities in behavioral despair tests. The results suggested that oral administration proanthocyanidin at doses of 25 and 50 mg/kg for 7 days significantly reduced the duration of immobility in both the tail suspension and forced swimming tests. The doses that affected the immobile response did not affect locomotor activity. In addn., the neurochem. and neuropharmacol. assays showed that proanthocyanidin produced a marked increase of 5-HT levels at 25 and 50 mg/kg in three brain regions, the frontal cortex, hippocampus and hypothalamus. Noradrenaline and dopamine levels were also increased when higher dose of proanthocyanidin (50 mg/kg) administration both in the frontal cortex and hippocampus. These effects were similar to those obsd. for the classical antidepressant imipramine (10 mg/kg, i.p.). Moreover, Our study suggested that proanthocyanidin (12.5, 25 and 50 mg/kg) dose dependently inhibited monoamine oxidase-A (MAO-A) activity, while MAO-B inhibitory activity was also found at higher doses (25 and 50 mg/kg) after 7 days administration. MAO-A selective inhibitor, moclobemide (20 mg/kg, i.g.) produced MAO-A inhibition of 70.5% in the mouse brain. These findings suggest that the antidepressant-like effects of proanthocyanidin may involve the central monoaminergic neurotransmitter systems.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsFantb7J&md5=01b9f0e959e9dbd98e841131170f4d67
    45. 45
      Drigues, N.; Poltyrev, T.; Bejar, C.; Weinstock, M.; Youdim, M. B. cDna Gene Expression Profile Of Rat Hippocampus After Chronic Treatment With Antidepressant Drugs. J. Neural Transm. 2003, 110, 1413– 1436,  DOI: 10.1007/s00702-003-0077-8
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      45
      cDNA gene expression profile of rat hippocampus after chronic treatment with antidepressant drugs
      Drigues, N.; Poltyrev, T.; Bejar, C.; Weinstock, M.; Youdim, M. B. H.
      Journal of Neural Transmission (2003), 110 (12), 1413-1436CODEN: JNTRF3; ISSN:0300-9564. (Springer-Verlag Wien)
      Background. Chronic antidepressant treatment causes alterations in several hippocampal genes, which participate in neuronal plasticity. However the full picture of their mechanism of action is not known. The advent of genomics enables to identify a broader mechanism of action and identify novel targets for antidepressant development. Methods. The present study examd. the cDNA microarray gene expression profile in the hippocampus induced by chronic antidepressant treatment, in rats exposed to the forced swim test. Animals were treated for 2 wk with moclobemide, clorgyline and amitriptyline. Results. The three antidepressants significantly reduced immobility in the forced swim test and initiated significant homologous changes in gene expressions. These include up regulation of cAMP response element binding protein and down regulation of corticotrophin releasing hormone. Other gene changes noted were those related to neuropeptides, neurogenesis and synaptogenesis, including synaptophysin and neogenin. Some 89 genes were changed by at least 2 drugs, out of which 53 were changed oppositely by forced swim test. Confirmation of gene changes, have come from real time RT-PCR. Conclusions. A significant no. and homol. in gene expression were obsd. with the three antidepressants. Many of the genes were assocd. with neurogenesis and synaptogenesis, including synaptophysin and neogenin.

      46
      The present status of monoamine oxidase inhibitors
      Pare C M
      The British journal of psychiatry : the journal of mental science (1985), 146 (), 576-84 ISSN:0007-1250.
      The present status of monoamine oxidase inhibitors in the treatment of depression is reviewed. With adequate doses they are effective antidepressants, but dosages have in the past been too low. Provided proper dietary precautions are taken, the incidence of fatality from dietary interactions is very small and should not deter doctors from using these drugs, especially in those depressed patients who do not respond to tricyclic-type antidepressants. The present status of combining monoamine oxidase inhibitors with tricyclics is discussed, as are the newer specific inhibitors particularly clorgyline and deprenyl.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADyaL2M3ltlGmtA%253D%253D&md5=5a54105f1b63320f7ef49f2fdd710925
    47. 47
      Baker, G. B.; Coutts, R. T.; McKenna, K. F.; Sherry-McKenna, R. Insights Into The Mechanisms Of Action Of The MAO Inhibitors Phenelzine And Tranylcypromine: A Review. J. Psychiatr. Neurosci. 1992, 17, 206– 214
      [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      47
      Insights into the mechanisms of action of the MAO inhibitors phenelzine and tranylcypromine: a review
      Baker G B; Coutts R T; McKenna K F; Sherry-McKenna R L
      Journal of psychiatry & neuroscience : JPN (1992), 17 (5), 206-14 ISSN:1180-4882.
      Although the non-selective monoamine oxidase inhibitors phenelzine and tranylcypromine have been used for many years, much still remains to be understood about their mechanisms of action. Other factors, in addition to the inhibition of monoamine oxidase and the subsequent elevation of brain levels of the catecholamines and 5-hydroxytryptamine, may contribute to the overall pharmacological profiles of these drugs. This review also considers the effects on brain levels of amino acids and trace amines, uptake and release of neurotransmitter amines at nerve terminals, receptors for amino acids and amines, and enzymes other than monoamine oxidase, including enzymes involved in metabolism of other drugs. The possible contributions of metabolism and stereochemistry to the actions of these monoamine oxidase inhibitors are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADyaK3s7ksVaqug%253D%253D&md5=290dbaddc5da35c7cee4253a0a8ace7a
    48. 48
      Stassen, H.; Angst, J.; Delini-Stula, A. Onset of improvement under fluoxetine and moclobemide. Eur. Psychiatr. 1998, 13, 128– 133,  DOI: 10.1016/S0924-9338(98)80135-1
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      48
      Onset of improvement under fluoxetine and moclobemide
      Stassen H; Angst J; Delini-Stula A
      European psychiatry : the journal of the Association of European Psychiatrists (1998), 13 (3), 128-33 ISSN:0924-9338.
      In a meta-analysis of the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor fluoxetine (n = 440) and the reversible and selective monoamine oxidase-A inhibitor moclobemide (n = 437) we investigated the time course of improvement over 6 weeks for these two classes of anti-depressants. Two different methods of approach were applied: (1) repeated measurement analysis of variance in combination with regression analysis, and (2) a survival-analytical approach that allowed us to determine onset of improvement for the individual patient, to distinguish between early and late improvers, to assess the predictive value of early improvement, and to adequately process premature withdrawals. The two antidepressants of large biochemical and pharmacological differences yielded virtually identical response- and drop-out rates, and exhibited no difference with respect to the time course of improvement. Onset of improvement occurred in more than half of the patients within the first 2 weeks of treatment, and early improvement was highly predictive of later outcome. In particular, there was no indication for a delayed onset of action of antidepressants. We suggest that future studies should be standardised with respect to washout period and sufficiently dense assessments during the first 2 weeks of trial. Thus, patient samples can be subdivided reproducibly into early-, late-, partial- and non-remitters. This, in turn, may help to identify "true" drug responders, and to discover why in some patients recovery becomes "stuck". Data already held by the pharmaceutical companies should be reanalysed in this respect.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD1Mrnt1Khug%253D%253D&md5=b5865109528c86ba590adfb322b3dc62
    49. 49
      Barbelivien, A.; Nyman, L.; Haapalinna, A.; Sirvio, J. Inhibition Of MAO-A Activity Enhances Behavioural Activity Of Rats Assessed Using Water Maze And Open Arena Tasks. Pharmacol. Toxicol. 2001, 88, 304– 312,  DOI: 10.1034/j.1600-0773.2001.880604.x
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      49
      Inhibition of MAO-A activity enhances behavioural activity of rats assessed using water maze and open arena tasks
      Barbelivien, Alexandra; Nyman, Leena; Haapalinna, Antti; Sirvio, Jouni
      Pharmacology & Toxicology (Copenhagen, Denmark) (2001), 88 (6), 304-312CODEN: PHTOEH; ISSN:0901-9928. (Munksgaard International Publishers Ltd.)
      To det. if the inhibition of MAO-A and/or MAO-B activities can influence cognitive processes in adult rats, we analyzed whether chronic treatment with clorgyline, 1-deprenyl and pargyline could modify the performance of adult rats in a modified version of the water maze task. The effects of these treatments on locomotor activity and enzyme activities were also assessed. Rats were treated for 24 days with clorgyline (0.2 mg/kg), 1-deprenyl (0.25 mg/kg) and pargyline (1 or 10 mg/kg). The treatments were started two weeks before the water maze expt. and continued until the end of testing. The rats were trained to find a submerged platform (6 days:1 trial/day; 7 the day: probe trial). Over the next three days, locomotor activity was assessed in an open arena. Treatments with clorgyline (MAO-A inhibitor), 1-deprenyl (MAO-B inhibitor) and pargyline (non-selective MAO inhibitor) did not improve the finding of the hidden platform, when compared to treatment with saline, but significantly increased the swimming speed of the rats. The different treatments, when compared to saline, failed to modify the distance covered and the no. of groomings performed in the open arena. However, clorgyline and pargyline, 10 mg/kg, increased the no. of fecal boli and clorgyline enhanced the no. of rearings made when compared to saline, 1-deprenyl and pargyline, 10 mg/kg. These results indicate that near total inhibition of MAO-A by clorgyline and pargyline as assessed by MAO activity measurement induces an increase in locomotor activity but that inhibition of MAO-A or MAO-B, either alone or combined, does not facilitate spatial learning in adult rats.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXltVehs7s%253D&md5=50c703d74d811fcd2fb3744a1a051966

      Aldol condensations of arom. aldehydes with ketones under solvent-free conditions to synthesize α,β-unsatd. ketones in good to excellent yields using PEG400 and powd. anhyd. K2CO3 as catalysts at 90°C and 120°C are described.

      Syntheses in the indene series
      Koo, John
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1953), 75 (), 2000-1CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      For a projected synthesis of colchicine analogs, various substituted indenes were prepd. as model compds. Substituents were introduced which, by cyclization, could yield tricyclic systems. 3,4-(MeO)2C6H3CHO (182.6 g.), 130 g. AcCH2CO2Et, and 70 cc. C6H6 refluxed 2 hrs. with 3.4 g. piperidine and 12.2 cc. AcOH (water trap), the cooled soln. dild. with 300 cc. Et2O, and the solvents removed yielded 175 g. Et veratrylideneacetoacetate (I), b1 190-2°, m. 75-81°. Piperonal by the method used for I yielded 62% Et piperonylideneacetoacetate (II), b1.6 179°, m. 75-81°. I (139 g.) in 150 cc. EtOAc hydrogenated 2 hrs. at room temp. and 45 lb. pressure over 9 g. 5% Pd-C yielded 100 g. Et veratrylacetoacetate (IIA), b1 169°; 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazone, m. 116-17°. Hydrogenation of II yielded 52% Et piperonylacetoacetate (III), b0.8 151-3°. Veratrylideneacetone, m. 84-6°, (69 g.) in 150 cc. AcOH reduced 35 min. over 5 g. Pd-C yielded 83% veratrylacetone (IV), b0.5 127-9°, m. 53-6°. Veratrylideneacetophenone, m. 90-2°, hydrogenated 4 hrs. in EtOAc over Pd-C yielded 93% veratrylacetophenone (V), m. 68-70°. IIA (56 g.) in 45 cc. 85% H3PO4 added slowly to 90 cc. H2SO4 contg. 45 cc. 85% H3PO4 at 0-5°, the mixt. stirred into ice water, filtered, the solid dissolved in Et2O, washed with 10% NaHCO3, and the solvent evapd. yielded 24 g. Et 5,6-dimethoxy-3-methyl-2-indenecarboxylate (VI), m. 136-6.5°. Acidification of the NaHCO3 washings yielded 5 g. free acid, m. 228-30°. III (1 g.) in 3 cc. each of H2SO4 and H3PO4 allowed to stand 40 min. at 0° and treated as above yielded 0.79 g. Et 5,6-methylenedioxy-3-methyl-2-indenecarboxylate, m. 107-8°; the washings yielded 0.032 g. free acid, m. 280-1°. IV (21 g.) in 42 cc. each H2SO4 and H3PO4 at 10-15° treated by the method used for VI (NaHCO3 washing omitted) except that the product was poured into 400 cc. of ice water after 0.5 hr., yielded 52% 5,6-dimethoxy-3-methylindene, m. 132-3°. V (the reaction mixt. heated 30 min. at 60-70°) yielded 5,6-dimethoxy-3-phenylindene (VII), m. 112-13.5°. Na (1.15 g.) in 50 cc. warm abs. EtOH treated rapidly with 7.5 g. (CO2Et)2, then with 18 g. VI in 100 cc. hot abs. EtOH, and the mixt. shaken 2 min., stirred into cold water, acidified with dil. HCl and filtered yielded 19 g. Et 1-ethoxalyl-5,6-dimethoxy-3-methyl-2-indenecarboxylate, m. 143-6°; 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazone, m. 180-2°; enol acetate, m. 132-3°. Na (0.46 g.), 15 cc. EtOH, 3 g. (CO2Et)2, and 4.2 g. VII yielded 76% 1-ethoxalyl-5,6-dimethoxy-3-phenylindene, m. 122-4°; enol acetate, m. 165-7°. VI (1 g.) in 15 cc. AcOH hydrogenated 2.5 hrs. in 15 cc. AcOH at 60° and 40 lb. over 0.5 g. 5% Pd-C yielded 0.85 g. Et 5,6-di-methoxy-3-methyl-2-indancarboxylate (VIII), m. 48-9°; free acid, m. 176-7°.
